title: 114_s2609
content: The Agricultural Marketing Act of 1946 is amended to include a National Voluntary Bioengineered Food Labeling Standard under Subtitle E. This section defines key terms related to bioengineered food labeling. Subtitle E of the Agricultural Marketing Act of 1946 introduces a National Voluntary Bioengineered Food Labeling Standard. The section defines terms like bioengineering, food, and Secretary for clarity and consistency in labeling genetically modified foods. "Subtitle E of the Agricultural Marketing Act of 1946 establishes a national voluntary bioengineered food labeling standard, applying to any food labeling indicating the use of bioengineering in development or production." The Secretary must establish a national voluntary bioengineered food labeling standard within 2 years of enactment. This standard applies to bioengineered foods and those possibly produced using bioengineering. Regulations must be followed for labeling food as bioengineered. The Secretary must establish a national voluntary bioengineered food labeling standard within 2 years of enactment. This standard prohibits claims about food safety or quality based solely on bioengineering, determines allowable amounts of bioengineered substances in food, and establishes a process for labeling foods as bioengineered. State Food Labeling Standards: No State or political subdivision can establish or maintain any food labeling requirement for bioengineered foods in interstate commerce that is different from the national voluntary standard. SEC. 294. INFORMATION FOR CONSUMERS. The Secretary will provide science-based information on agricultural biotechnology benefits through education and outreach to address consumer acceptance. A mandatory report on bioengineered food information must be submitted to Congress within 4 years of enactment. The Secretary will provide information on agricultural biotechnology benefits through education and outreach. A mandatory report on bioengineered food information must be submitted to Congress within 4 years of enactment, including details on various federal acts and voluntary programs related to food production. Federal preemption prohibits states or political subdivisions from imposing labeling requirements on genetically engineered food or seed in interstate commerce. The term 'food' is defined as per the Federal Food, Drug, and Cosmetic Act. The Secretary of Agriculture determines terms related to genetic engineering.
